for academic literacies. Multiple drafts of composing projects in a variety of
genres and modes with feedback from peers and the instructor.
prereq: Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

name: Visualizing Society
description:
Analysis and visualization of historical and contemporary data about
populations and societies using R. Critical exploration of visual
communication of information about people over time and critical assessment of
role of data collection and analysis in societies.

name: Writing in Science
description:
Writing abstracts, research proposals, scientific papers, other forms of
scientific communication. Presenting data graphically. Primarily for students
engaged in or planning careers in basic or applied research.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL
003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-

standing or enrollment in a graduate science curriculum.

name: Complex Organizations
description:
Develops a sociological approach to organizations theory. Designed to
introduce sociological concepts, address the alternative psychological and
economic models, and involve students in the practice of organizational
analysis.

name: Cognitive Neuroscience
description:
Neuroscientific foundations of higher mental processes including attention,
memory, language, higher-level perceptual and motor processes, and
consciousness. Emphasis on the neural mechanisms which form the substrates of
human cognition and the relationship of mind to brain.
prereq:
(PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; or Consent of Instructor. PSC 101, PSC 121, or
PSC 129 recommended.

name: Democracy
description: Examination of conditions promoting democratization and democratic stability.

name: Journalism

003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C-

name: Elem Part Physics
description:
Properties and classification of elementary particles and their interactions.
Experimental techniques. Conservation laws and symmetries. Strong,
electromagnetic, and weak interactions. Introduction to Feynman calculus.
prereq: PHY 115A C- or better; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Style & Cultural Studies
description:
Multiple and overlapping influences of gender, sexuality, ethnicity, and class
on constructions of identity and community are explored through the study of
style in popular culture and everyday life. Continuity and change in clothing
and appearance styles are interpreted.

name: Intro Comp Politics
description:
Introduction to basic concepts in political analysis and application of them
in comparative studies of selected countries. Coverage is given to cultural
and other informal dimensions of politics as well as to more formal political
and governmental structures.

name: Advanced Composition
description:
Instruction in advanced principles of expository writing. Writing tasks within
and beyond the University. Different writing modes, including narrative,
analysis, explanation, argument, critique. May be taught abroad.
prereq:
UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM
001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C-
or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division
standing.

name: Solid State Physics
description:
Survey of fundamental ideas in the physics of solids, with selected device
applications. Crystal structure, x-ray and neutron diffraction, phonons,
simple metals, energy bands and Fermi surfaces, semiconductors, optical
properties, magnetism, superconductivity.
prereq:
PHY 115A C- or better; or equivalent course passed with C- or better, or
consent of instructor.

name: Intro to Cosmology
description:
Contemporary knowledge regarding the origin of the universe, including the Big
Bang and nucleosynthesis, microwave background radiation, formation of cosmic
structure, cosmic inflation, cosmic acceleration and dark energy.
prereq:
PHY 009A; PHY 009B; PHY 009C; PHY 009D; PHY 105A { can be concurrent }; or
Consent of Instructor. PHY 105A required concurrently.

name: College Writing-SCC157S

name: Gender
description:
Analysis of biological, psychological, cultural and structural conditions
underlying the status and roles of men and women in contemporary society,
drawing on a historical and comparative perspective.

description:

relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning
careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy,
optometry.

description:
Writing course focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies,
exploring ways to understand a writing task; to develop appropriate content

name: Wine Stability Lab

Practical application of principles of equilibria and rates of physical and

prereq: VEN 126 { can be concurrent }; VEN 123L; and Consent of Instructor.

Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the idea of fundamentalism

Soil Microbiology
description:
Major groups of microorganisms in soil, their interrelationships, and their

nutrients. Plant-microbe relationships. Transformations of organic and
inorganic pollutants.

name: General Physics
description:
Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for

name: Laboratory Research
description:
Training in specific lab-based research methods coupled with hands-on
experience in a research lab. Students assessed on their ability report and
interpret research findings. Content varies from quarter to quarter.

The student, through fieldwork in a community health agency, learns to apply

description:
Varieties of categorical data, cross-classifications, contingency tables,
tests for independence. Multidimensional tables and log-linear models, maximum
likelihood estimation; tests of goodness-of-fit. Logit models, linear logistic
models. Analysis of incomplete tables. Packaged computer programs, analysis of
real data.

description:
Introduction to the basic principles of the scientific study of politics.
Research design and empirical analysis of data with applications to different
methodological approaches and different substantive areas in political
science.

name: Rules of Electoral Game
description:
Analysis of laws and court cases on the organization and administration of
elections in the United States. Topics include campaign finance,
redistricting, voting rights, race and representation, and comparisons with
other democracies.

name: Special Study
description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

name: Honors Physics
description: Application of quantum mechanics.

name: Social Psychology
description:
Behavior of the individual in the group. Examination of basic psychological
processes in social situations, surveying various problems of social
interaction: group tensions, norm-development, attitudes, values, public
opinion, status.

name: Global Climate Change
description:
Causes of global climate change and the biological, geophysical, and social
consequences of such change. Methods used by different scientists for
predicting future events. Complexity of global affairs. Decision making under
uncertainty.

description:

Supervised preparation of an extensive paper relating internship experience to
concepts, literature, and theory of political science.
prereq:

name: Pol Theory: Early Modern
description:
Critical analysis of the works of early modern political philosophers such as
Machiavelli, Montaigne, Hobbes, Locke and Hume.

name: South Asian Religions
description:
Introduction to South Asian religions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam,
Jainism and Sikhism. Traces historical developments from Vedic texts and their
ascetic reformulation by sages such as Yajnavalkya, Siddhartha Gautama, and
Mahavira into our global present.

name: Intro/Wine Making
description:
Overview of the history of wine, viticulture, fermentation, winery operations,
the physiology of wine consumption, wines produced in California and other
major wine-producing regions and the sensory evaluation of wine. May be taught
abroad.

Analysis of American elections and partisan behavior; political socialization,
political participation, partisanship and individual and group determinants of
voting.

description:
International politics of the Middle East as a microcosm of world politics.
The Middle East as a regional system. Domestic and International Politics in
the Middle East. Changing Political Structures in the Middle East. Superpower
involvement in the Middle East.

name: Plant Morphology
description:
Introduction to the form, development and evolution of vascular plants.
Emphasis given to the form and development of reproductive structures in ferns
and seed-producing plants as a basis for determining evolutionary
relationships.

name: Critical Reasoning
description:
Criteria of good reasoning in everyday life and in science. Topics to be
covered may include basic principles of deduction and induction; fallacies in
reasoning; techniques and aids to reasoning; principles of scientific
investigation; aids to clarity.

Principles of research writing. Analysis and development of research topics

Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across

prereq: Students placed into the course via AWPE score of 4 or lower.

description:
Advanced instruction in writing for Social Justice, using an interdisciplinary

transnational studies; practice in techniques of research and styles of
communication for diverse audiences. Suitable for activists in community
organizing, non-profits, politics.

name: Soils in Viticulture
description:
Landscape distribution, physical and chemical processes in viticultural soils.
Site evaluation procedures, best soil management practices, vineyard
fertilization, and soil health monitoring.

package.

Development of academic writing, critical thinking, and reading skills.
Development of clear, accurate language for presenting an effective argument.

description:
Psychological factors influencing health and illness. Topics include stress
and coping, personality and health, symptom perception and reporting, heart
disease, cancer, compliance, and health maintenance and promotion.

Continuation of PHY 116A. Introduction to the use of digital electronics and
microcomputers in experimental physics. Nonlinear electronics, integrated
circuits, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters, transducers,
actuators.
prereq: PHY 009C or PHY 009HD; or Consent of Instructor.

name: Perception
description:
Cognitive organizations related to measurable physical energy changes mediated

relationships. Topics include relationship development, relationship
maintenance, and relationship loss.

Seminar on topics related to alternative theories, practices and systems of
agriculture and the relationship of agriculture to the environment and
society. Scientific, technological, social, political and economic
perspectives.
prereq: Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

Principles of the cellular mechanisms and hormonal regulation underlying plant
growth, development, and reproduction. Emphasis on how these processes
contribute to the harvestable yield of cultivated plants and can be managed to
increase crop productivity and quality.
prereq: PLS 100A; Or the equivalent of PLS 100A.

name: Directed Group Study
description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

name: Neuroeconomics&Decisions
description:
Theoretical and empirical approaches to neuroeconomics (neuroscience of
decision making) from psychology, neuroscience, economics, and computer
science. Neuroscience of judgment and decision making, behavioral economics,
and reinforcement learning.

name: Principles Lit Criticism
description:
Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, drama,
poetry, and essay of major literary writers of the Hispanic world.

name: Writing in Health Prof
description:
Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing

optometry.

standing.

name: Intro Gender Studies
description:
Introduction to interdisciplinary, critical gender studies. Addresses the
